By 2014, she had been promoted to editor in chief of the award-winning site, where she continued to enhance programming, adding restaurant reviews, videos, news features and even some investigations around the #MeToo movement in the restaurant industry. Ms. Kludt, 34, lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, with her husband, Pablo Douzoglou, 33, who works in marketing for an independent record label, and their son, Ansel Kludt, 22 months.

title: House Republicans Release Secret Memo Accusing Russia Investigators of Bias
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans released a politically charged memo on Friday that accused F.B.I. and Justice Department leaders of abusing their surveillance powers to spy on a former Trump campaign adviser suspected of being an agent of Russia.

title: Tallying Wells Fargos Penalties: DealBook Briefing
description: Good Friday. Heres what were watching:

title: About 90 Migrants Feared Dead After Boat Capsizes Near Libya
description: GENEVA  The United Nations is investigating a sudden increase in Pakistani migrants trying to make the perilous sea crossing to Europe, its migration agency said on Friday, after a smugglers boat foundered off the coast of Libya leaving 90 people feared drowned.

title: Your Week in Culture: Kendrick Lamars Black Panther, Paul Klee, Lesley Manville
description: New TV shows, museum openings, film releases and concerts  its a lot to keep track of. Let us help you. For the week of Feb. 4, seven events in New York and elsewhere not to be missed:

title: Trumps (Other) Memo Cover-Up
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

title: Farhads Week in Tech: Less Time on Facebook, More Noise From Amazon
description: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo, The Timess technology columnist, reviews the weeks news, offering analysis (and maybe a joke or two) about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

title: Two Penthouses Sell for $60 Million, and John Mellencamp Buys in SoHo
description: The new year began almost the same way as 2017 ended: with outsize closings of combination-ready penthouses at 432 Park Avenue.

title: The Simpsons Has Predicted a Lot. Most of It Can Be Explained.
description: There is no crystal ball in The Simpsons writers room, but youd be forgiven for wondering.

title: California Today: Hot Winter Means Snowpack Is Far Below Normal
description: Good morning.

title: Yes, You Can Find a Financial Planner Even if Youre Not Rich
description: Please help me find reasonably priced financial advice from someone who wont rob me blind.

title: Let the Pre-Oscar Bingeing Begin
description: The range of films nominated for the 90th Academy Awards seems wider than average, and thats gratifying. There are the nominations that move the needle a little in terms of making the American film industry less white-male dominated.

title: Here and Now, a New Supernatural Drama From the Creator of True Blood
description: LOS ANGELES  If Alan Ball has learned anything from his decades in television, its that an hourlong television show doesnt need to be neatly categorized. This Georgia-born writers series Six Feet Under, after all, was a dark comedy about a diversely dysfunctional funeral home family, while his True Blood, based on the Southern Vampire Mysteries novels by Charlaine Harris, combined elements of fantasy, horror, bodice-ripping ardor and  why not?  family, too.

title: Watch the Met Opera Stage a Sea of Blood
description: When it comes to blood, Quentin Tarantino has nothing on the Metropolitan Opera. Stabbings, shootings, torture and beheadings are routine at the Met. But the bloodiest show of them all may be Franois Girards production of Wagners Parsifal, which returns on Feb. 5 and floods the theaters vast stage with some 1,250 gallons of the stuff.

title: How to Bid for the N.F.L.s Biggest Prize: Team Ownership
description: After the last down is played and a new Super Bowl champion hoists the Lombardi Trophy on Sunday, the focus of the National Football League will turn to another prize: the sale of one of its 32 teams. The winning bidder will pay a huge sum for a property that is as close to a guarantee of fame and fortune as there can be.

title: Victims Father Lunges at Larry Nassar in Court
description: A father of two young women who gave victim impact statements at the sentencing hearing of Lawrence G. Nassar was tackled by law enforcement officials when he rushed at the former sports medicine doctor across a courtroom on Friday.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Good morning. Super Bowl festivities are already underway in Minneapolis, where the New England Patriots will square off against the Philadelphia Eagles on Sunday night, and maybe youll greet the game with regional eats.

title: A Homeland Spy Opens Up Onstage in Returning to Reims
description: In the fall of 2016, the German actress Nina Hoss followed the American presidential campaign up close: She was in New York, shooting the sixth season of Homeland, in which she played a fan favorite, the intelligence agent Astrid. It was time to go home to Berlin, where she was scheduled to return to theater; she was considering performing The Human Voice, Jean Cocteaus 1930 monologue that consists entirely of a woman pleading on the phone. But the election of Donald J. Trump changed Ms. Hosss plans.

title: We Answered Your Questions About Writing for The Edit
description: The Reader Center is one way we in the newsroom are trying to connect with you, by highlighting your perspectives and experiences and offering insight into how we work.

title: Pierre God, Top Adviser to Frances Richest Man, Dies at 73
description: Pierre God, a French lawyer whose steely negotiation skills and strategic vision made him the minence grise of the worlds largest luxury group, LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, has died in Nice, France. He was 73.

title: RuPauls Drag Race All Stars: Dueling Divas
description: The second episode of RuPauls Drag Race All Stars could very well be summed up in one word: gross. But more on that later.

title: If Immigrants Are Pushed Out, Who Will Care for the Elderly?
description: In Dallas, a 93-year-old is worried about the woman who, for years, has come to her house four days a week to help with shopping, laundry, housecleaning and driving. Shes just a wonderful person, someone I feel I can trust completely, said the older woman.

title: New Sentences: From Fire Sermon, by Jamie Quatro
description: From Fire Sermon (Grove Press, 2018, Page 127), by Jamie Quatro. Fire Sermon is Quatros first novel, following the short-story collection I Want to Show You More.

title: Poem: Beginning With a Horse
description: Selected by Terrance Hayes

title: The 1.21.18 Issue
description: RE: Cryptocurrency

title: Behind the Cover: 2.4.18
description: Jake Silverstein, editor in chief: Idris Khans layered image of speedskaters is a riot of arms and legs and determined faces  a perfect cover image, we think, for an Olympics Issue focused on the unique appeal and the phenomenal physical challenges involved in each sport of the Winter Games.

title: How to Overcome Seasickness
description: Dont fight it, says Alexus Kwachka, a commercial fisherman from Kodiak, Alaska, who still gets seasick even after 30 years of traveling between the Bering Strait and the Gulf of Alaska. Go to the rail and puke as soon as you can. Do so over the leeward side of the boat, facing downwind. Dont feel ashamed. For Kwachka, it helps to keep the mood light. He tells the crew hes going to look for Buicks, vomits over the side and then sneezes. That seems to reset things, he says.

title: Putin the Campaigner: Scripted and Awkward, Save One Big Hug
description: UFA, Russia  As President Vladimir V. Putin was about to step out onto the gleaming white cement floor of the Ufa Engine Industrial Association, where motors are assembled for military helicopters, Alyona V. Popova was busy organizing her work station, more out of nerves than necessity.

title: Judge John Hodgman on the Importance of Proper Name Pronunciation
description: Lauren writes: My best friends name is Laura, but we pronounce the first syllable differently. I say Lauren like Lawrence. She says Laura like Lara. A complication: She is named after her mother, and they both pronounce it this way! I am not named after anyone. Im not asking you to order Laura to change her pronunciation. But I would like to know, officially, who is correct and who is living a lie.

title: A New Cocktail Conference With a Political Twist
description: Chicago will host a new cocktail conference this spring. Called Chicago Style, it will take place May 7 to 10, after the gala for the James Beard Awards.

title: Sedate a Plant, and It Seems to Lose Consciousness. Is It Conscious?
description: Plants dont get enough credit.

title: The Women Behind White Power
description: Few Americans know the name Cornelia Dabney Tucker, but the Jim Crow South would not have been the same without her.

title: Jacques dAmboise: Apollo at 83
description: Jacques dAmboise, the great American ballet dancer, is in possession of laughing eyes and a crop of white hair, and he knows how to turn an interview into a show. Wandering through the art-lined hallways of the National Dance Institute in Harlem on a recent afternoon, he gave the best kind of performance  around every corner, there was a new surprise, a new story.

title: Childrens Books About Black History, Heavy on Biographies
description: History is a story like any other, but black history is a story so devoid of logic that it frustrates the young reader. The young readers in my house, told of slavery and segregation, asked in disbelief: What? Why?

title: Border Percussion: The 8 Best Classical Music Moments of the Week on YouTube
description: Our critics and reporters offer a glimpse of whats moved and delighted them on YouTube. Read the rest of our classical music coverage here.

title: Antiques and the Arts
description: Benefits were held for Tony Bennetts Exploring the Arts, the National Cares Mentoring Movement and East Side House Settlement.

title: A Sportswriters First Impressions of Pyeongchang
description: GANGNEUNG, South Korea  Early Friday morning, in a hallway outside the Olympic media dining room, a young woman stocked a long row of shelves with Korean novels translated into a dozen or so languages. The books were free to take or borrow, she said. The Pyeongchang Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games hoped to introduce international visitors to Korean literature and other aspects of the national culture.

title: An Artist Wants to Build a U.F.O. Next to Edvard Munchs Studio
description: OSLO  For the last 28 years of his life, the artist Edvard Munch lived in a villa in a hilly, forested area that was then on the outskirts of this city. He completed hundreds of paintings and drawings there, and the estate,  Ekely, has become a pilgrimage site for fans of his art. Although Munchs villa was demolished in 1960, and an artists colony now exists on the site, his enclosed winter studio remains, and visitors can walk among the nearby trees to discover the surroundings that inspired many of his later works.

title: Calamari Goes Beyond the Fryer and Into a Braise
description: When the question is whats for dinner? the Italian word calamari makes a nicer-sounding answer than squid. And squid for supper sounds better than the scientific cephalopod, the class of seafood to which it belongs.

title: St. Martin Starts a Comeback
description: The Caribbean island of St. Martin is on the road to recovery following the severe damage it sustained from last summers Hurricane Irma (Hurricane Maria had a minor impact on St. Martin).

title: Funeral Homes Slow to Put Prices Online
description: Even as consumers increasingly shop and compare prices on the web, one group of businesses remains slow to put cost information online: funeral homes.

title: The Bad News in the Good News
description: This mornings job market report was definitely good. Job creation was surprisingly strong for this late in an economic expansion; wages are finally rising, although still far more slowly than they were before the Great Recession. You never want to make too much of one months report, but this was clearly positive.

title: Remind Me, Why Was It That We Ever Watched Infomercials?
description: Print headline: The Stepford Channel, published here in October 1992.

title: A Sheet-Pan Supper That Defies the Seasons
description: For most of the year, I hold to the notion that what grows together goes together, especially when it comes to mingling things on a sheet pan.

title: Review: In Bladder Inn, Waiting for Dancers to Wander Away
description: What if a group of dancers, mid-performance, just wandered away and didnt come back? On Thursday at Danspace Project, during the premiere of Mina Nishimuras Bladder Inn (and X, Y, Z, W), such a development often seemed imminent. In a loosely knit hourlong show that spilled from the sanctuary of St. Marks Church into its back rooms and balconies, Ms. Nishimura, one of eight dancers, created not so much a world as an atmosphere, a web of activity on the brink of dissolving.

title: Rose McGowan on Brave
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: Yellen, Departing Fed, Will Join Brookings
description: WASHINGTON  Janet L. Yellen, who completed her term as Federal Reserve chairwoman on Friday, plans to start a new job on Monday morning as a fellow in economic studies at the Brookings Institution.

title: Why Womens Voices Are Scarce in Economics
description: For decades, the number of women studying economics seemed to be increasing, easing the persistent scarcity of professional female economists in the United States. But that progress has stalled.

title: Protecting Your Reputation When Youre Ready to Go
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes From the Book Review Archives
description: In this weeks issue, Bill McKibben reviews Charles C. Manns new double biography of William Vogt and Norman Bourlag. In 1948, Robert C. Cook reviewed Vogts Road to Survival, an eloquent treatise on earths future that Mann argues birthed modern environmentalism. Read an excerpt below.

title: Auction Houses Thrived in 2017, in an 18th-Century Way
description: LONDON  The international auction houses are feeling bullish once again.

title: Review: Field Guide Brings Standup to a Dostoyevsky Downer
description: NEW HAVEN  Have you ever wanted to see a towering novel of moral anguish reduced to an 80-minute romp? Oh, good: me, too.

title: Reported Cases of Sexual Abuse Against Men Triple in England and Wales
description: LONDON  It took one man 32 years to speak out about the time he was raped by a group of older boys at his high school in Britain, and three more years before he reported the attack to the police.

title: Danielle Steel: I Know an Idea Is Right for Me When It Just Clicks
description: STEEL WORK: It might surprise you to learn that Danielle Steel  who has written 167 books and will publish six more in 2018  spends between two and three years on each title. Sometimes I just sit and stare into space and think about a book, or a twist in a book, or the kernel of an idea, and I follow the thought for a while and see where it goes, and try to envision it, she explains. I know when an idea is right for me when it just clicks, and I can tell in my gut its the one. But she doesnt immediately dive into a manuscript. I make notes for a while before I start work on the outline. The notes are usually more about the characters. I need to know the characters really well before I start  who they are, how they think, how they feel, what has happened to them, how they grew up.

title: Paperback Row
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

title: The Stock Market Works by Day, but It Loves the Night
description: The daytime is for losers. Overnight is when the big money is made in the stock market  not by trading but by getting a good nights sleep.

title: A West Virginia Newspaper Won Journalisms Top Award. Now Its Filed for Bankruptcy.
description: For decades, The Charleston Gazette-Mail in West Virginia has exposed corruption, greed and incompetence with a tenacity that was rewarded last year with journalisms highest honor, a Pulitzer Prize. But the newspaper now faces a painful reality: No matter how strong its journalism, no publication is immune to the economic pressure on the industry.

title: Read the Nunes Memo, Annotated
description: A previously secret memo released on Friday claims that F.B.I. officials abused their authority and favored Democrats in the early stages of the Russia investigation. Read our reporters annotations.

title: Iran Arrests 29 Linked to Protests Against Compulsory Hijab
description: TEHRAN  Twenty-nine people, most of them women, have been arrested in connection with recent protests in Iran against the compulsory Islamic veil for women, the police in Tehran said on Friday, adding that the protesters had been deceived by foreign forces.

title: The Nunes Memo vs. the Schiff Memo
description: There are now two memos agitating Washington. One from Representative Devin Nunes and one from Representative Adam B. Schiff. Feeling confused? Youre not alone.

title: Love Notes
description: Before #MeToo and Cat Person and Graces very bad date with Aziz, before Harvey Weinstein and Roy Moore and His-Name-Here, before Stormy Daniels and the grab em tape  before the whole stomach-churning, hair-pulling snarl of it all  there were romance novels. Blessed, blissful escape.

title: Arizona Man Is Charged With Making Armor-Piercing Bullets Found in Las Vegas Gunmans Room
description: CHANDLER, Ariz.  An ammunition dealer who had been named a person of interest in connection with the Las Vegas mass shooting was charged in a Nevada federal court Friday with manufacturing armor-piercing bullets. The charges came on the same day that the dealer, Douglas Haig, held a news conference to say he was innocent and had only briefly met the gunman, Stephen Paddock, when Mr. Paddock bought 720 rounds of ammunition from him in September.

title: In City Council, Power Shifts Away From Progressives
description: Four years ago, spurred on by a newly elected mayor who ran on a progressive agenda, an insurgent group of like-minded reformers took control of the City Council, standing up to the Democratic Party establishment and its powerful county bosses.

title: Lisa Hallidays Debut Novel Is Drawing Comparisons to Philip Roth. Though Not for the Reasons You Might Think.
description: In the opening scene of Lisa Hallidays debut novel, Asymmetry, Alice, a young editorial assistant at a publishing house, is reading on a bench on the Upper West Side when a famous novelist plops down beside her with a Mister Softee ice cream cone. When they meet again on the same bench two weeks later, the novelist, Ezra Blazer, brings two cones and offers her one. After she accepts it, quickly rationalizing that multiple-Pulitzer Prize winners dont go around poisoning people, Ezra asks her, Are you game?

title: Adding Captions to Images in Google Photos
description: Q. On Android, how do I add caption information to individual pictures I have stored online in a Google Photos album? The text edit tool in the Google Photos Help guide seems to just add a caption on the whole album.

title: An Up-and-Coming Designer Sets Her Sights on New York Fashion Week
description: Sandra Sandor has been designing for Nanushka, her Budapest-based womens wear label, for 13 years. But this is the first time she will be showing at New York Fashion Week, which starts Monday.

title: Gay in the Trump Era
description: To the Editor:

title: Review: At City Ballet, a Prettily Arcadian Dance Odyssey
description: As a dancer, Peter Walker, a dark-haired beanpole amid the New York City Ballet corps, has an unusually adult and purposeful look. He brings onto the stage the air of a life outside the theater. I believe in him so much as a character in performance (not least in plotless ballets) that I want to believe equally in the ballets he himself makes.

title: Online Learning Successes
description: To the Editor:

title: Flu Patients Arrive in Droves, and a Hospital Rolls Out the Surge Tent
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa.  By mid-January, the flu season at Lehigh Valley Hospital-Cedar Crest here in Allentown was bad enough to justify dragging out the surge tent.

title: Donor Names on a Border Wall
description: To the Editor:

title: Trustees at Michigan State
description: To the Editor:

title: Bachelor Contestant Was Reported Missing in November, but Shes Been in Plain Sight
description: When The North Coast Journal, an alternative weekly newspaper in Northern California, posted a story to Facebook about 35 people who were reported missing in Humboldt County, it asked its readers if they recognized any of the faces.

title: Kenya Government Defies Court Order to Restore TV Broadcasts
description: The Kenyan government is defying a court order to put four private television stations back on the air, escalating a week of political tensions and raising concerns about its respect for the rule of law.

title: Stocks Fall to End a Bad Week, and a Boom Begins to Look Shaky
description: Investors have spent much of the last year shrugging off geopolitical and economic risks, from the threat of nuclear conflict with North Korea to a potential trade war with China. Instead, they have focused on the strength of the United States economy, driven by banner corporate profits and President Trumps push to lower taxes and reduce regulation.

title: Listen to Still Processing
description: We dissect the public reaction to nipplegate and offer Janet Jackson the forgiveness she deserves.

title: Still Processing: Were Still Here For Janet
description: This week, in light of Justin Timberlakes coming Super Bowl halftime appearance, we revisit his infamous 2004 wardrobe malfunction performance with Janet Jackson. We dissect the public reaction to nipplegate, why Jackson (and not Timberlake) took the fall and how the controversy changed the course of both artists careers. We consider Timberlakes new musical direction in the context of his history of appropriating other cultures. And we offer Jackson the forgiveness she deserves, revisiting how her sexual experimentation led to some of our favorite moments in music history.

title: Popular Japanese Comedian Wants to Bring Her Plus-Size Fashion to the U.S.
description: Name Naomi Watanabe

title: The Playlist: The Weeknd and Kendrick Lamar Join Forces, and 15 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. This week, Iggy Azalea returns with Quavo, Girlpool teams with Dev Hynes, and Ed Sheeran writes a song for a boy band.

title: The Storm Around a G.O.P. Memo
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sprinkle, a Snapshot, a Sensation: My Dinner With Salt Bae
description: Halfway through dinner my lap was speckled with white crystals of salt dropped from the right hand of Salt Bae himself. Salt Bae hadnt meant to salt my trousers, as far as I could tell. He was aiming for the rib-eye on the table in front of me at his new Midtown restaurant, Nusr-Et Steakhouse, but he had raised his fingers up to his scalp line before he allowed the salt to start its free fall, and a good deal of it had gone wide of the mark.

title: Trump Calls Justice Department and F.B.I. Conduct a Disgrace
description: President Trump on Friday intensified his attacks on his own Justice Department and F.B.I. for their handling of the investigation into Russias interference in the 2016 elections, hinting that senior leaders there should face consequences for conduct he called a disgrace.

title: A New Job Description for M.T.A. Workers: Professionally Nice
description: Good morning all! Have a nice day!

title: Migrant Clashes in French City Lead to More Police, and Fears of More Violence
description: PARIS  A day after violent clashes in the northern French city of Calais injured at least 18 people and left four migrants in critical condition on Friday, local organizations and officials faced a lingering question: Could tensions among migrants spin further out of control?

title: Trumps Faux-Populist Infrastructure Plan
description: President Trump campaigned on  and continues to promise  a populist agenda, most recently in his State of the Union address, in which he called on Congress to pass a trillion-dollar infrastructure package. But if his rubbing shoulders with Davos elite last week werent enough to dispel any hopes of him delivering on his populist posturing, the emerging details of that infrastructure plan surely is.

title: Getting the Subway Moving (On Screen, at Least)
description: Serving almost six million riders a day and operating 24/7, the New York subway system is an icon of the city  and no small feat to run. So how did it get this bad?

title: 12 Shows Well Be Talking About in February
description: Watching is The New York Timess TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.

title: Review: Winchester Has a Grim Helen Mirren. And a Silly Script.
description: Released without fanfare or publicity screenings, the haunted-house movie Winchester would seem to lack the confidence of its makers. One soon sees why: Despite the typically elevating presence of Helen Mirren, this super-silly feature (the fifth from the Australian brothers Peter and Michael Spierig) stubbornly resists being classed up.

title: Smart Is Something You Get: How a Bronx School Succeeds
description: On a recent Monday morning, a Bronx kindergartner was making a list of vocabulary words that tripped him up in a story hed just read. Mitten was one, worm another.

title: U.S. Imposes Arms Ban on South Sudan as Civil War Grinds On
description: WASHINGTON  The United States banned the export of weapons and defense services to South Sudan on Friday in a reflection of the Trump administrations growing frustration over that nations grinding civil war.

title: Israel Moves to Expel Africans. Critics Say Thats Not Jewish.
description: JERUSALEM  On a recent weeknight, about two dozen Israelis, mostly in their 20s, gathered in a Jerusalem basement to hear the story of an Eritrean man who is facing deportation.

title: Force Overtime? Or Go for the Win?
description: On Jan. 16, 2016, with time expiring in the fourth quarter of a playoff game between the Green Bay Packers and the Arizona Cardinals, the Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers completed an improbable Hail Mary touchdown pass to bring the Packers within 1 point of the Cardinals.

title: Right and Left React to the Release of Nunes Memo
description: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. Thats why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

title: Some Syrian Refugees Are Going Back to War Alongside Turkey
description: KILIS, Turkey  Turkey is relying on a newly reconfigured, 20,000-member American-trained force with three army corps as it tries to carve out a buffer zone within Syria. The force has already taken 16 casualties in two weeks of fighting on the front lines.

title: First Female Editor of Bild, Influential German Tabloid, Steps Down
description: BERLIN  Tanit Koch, the first female editor in chief of Bild, Germanys best-selling newspaper, said on Friday that she was resigning after an apparent power struggle with another executive at the publication.

title: Cold-Stove League: Baseball and Union Lament Glacial Pace on Two Fronts
description: If you love baseball, you hate when people call it boring. Theres so much going on, its only boring to boring people, all that stuff.

title: Vail Dance Fest to Celebrate Its 30th Anniversary
description: New commissions, from Justin Peck, Lauren Lovette, Michelle Dorrance, Lil Buck, Claudia Schreier, Silas Riener and Rashaun Mitchell, as well as a choreographic debut by the New York City Ballet principal Tiler Peck, are among the highlights of this years Vail Dance Festival, which will run from July 28 through Aug. 11. The program, announced Friday, celebrates the festivals 30th anniversary with an emphasis on collaborative creative relationships.

title: Tariq Ramadan Charged With Rape After Accusations by Two Women
description: PARIS  Tariq Ramadan, a prominent Swiss-born scholar of Islam, was charged in France with rape on Friday, based on accusations made against him four months ago by two women. He has denied the accusations as a smear.

title: Who Is Tariq Ramadan?
description: As #MeToo takes hold in France, Mr. Ramadan, a world-renowned scholar of contemporary Islam, faces allegations of rape.

title: Accounting Investigation Adds to Challenges Facing G.E.
description: There is an old joke about an executive looking to hire a new accountant. He asks each candidate: What is one plus one? The winner answers: What do you want it to be?

title: Six Films to Stream if You Loved Call Me by Your Name
description: Watching is The New York Timess TV and film recommendation website. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter here.

title: When Percoco Improperly Used Cuomos Office, the Governor Was Often There
description: During the late spring and summer of 2014, Joseph Percoco was a very busy man, frequently coming and going from the Manhattan offices of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, often arriving by 9 a.m. and sometimes staying till sunset.

title: Leading Private Equity Firm Accused of Misusing Funds
description: The Abraaj Group has  a reputation as one of the developing worlds largest and most influential investors. The private equity firm, based in Dubai, in the United Arab Emirates, manages nearly $14 billion for institutions including development agencies in the United States, Britain and France.

title: What Were Reading
description: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What Were Reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

title: A Japanese Hockey Prodigy Eyes a Path to the N.H.L.
description: KARUIZAWA, Japan  At 14, Aito Iguchi is already an internet stickhandling sensation and a household name in Japanese youth hockey. The question wherever he plays is typically not whether, but when, he will stickhandle his way to a goal. But Iguchi wants more than goals.

title: 7 Takeaways From the Release of the Secret Memo
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans released a disputed memo on Friday that accused the F.B.I. and Justice Department of abusing their surveillance powers to spy on a former Trump campaign adviser, Carter Page.

title: Union Questions Mets Firing of Director for Remark to Chorister
description: When the Metropolitan Opera was told this week that a veteran British stage director had made a sexually charged remark to a member of the chorus, it acted swiftly and fired the director, stunning the opera world. On Friday, the union representing both the chorister and the director said it believed the incident could have been resolved to the satisfaction of both sides without dismissing the director.

title: Bonuses After Tax Cut Dont Always Live Up to Their Billing
description: Whats not to like? Scores of companies, including some of the countrys biggest employers, are handing out bonuses, announcing with a flourish that they are sharing the windfall from corporate tax cuts with their workers.

title: Devin Nunes, Flu Season, Groundhog Day: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Thank Progressives for the Nunes Memo
description: House Republicans released a secret memo on Friday that alleges that F.B.I. and Justice Department officials misused their authority in conducting surveillance of a former Trump campaign adviser, Carter Page. It also claims the officials abused the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act process by citing dubious information in their application for a warrant to wiretap Mr. Page.

title: Weve Got the Memo. Now What About Trumps Tax Returns?
description: Seriously? Thats all theyve got?

title: Louis Zorich, Familiar Actor on TV and Stage, Dies at 93
description: Louis Zorich, a busy actor who appeared on Broadway with stars like Laurence Olivier and Dustin Hoffman, on television in the comedy Mad About You and in numerous projects with his wife, the Oscar-winning actress Olympia Dukakis, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Federal Reserve Shackles Wells Fargo After Fraud Scandal
description: The Federal Reserve on Friday imposed unusually harsh penalties on Wells Fargo, punishing it for years of misconduct and barring it from future growth until the bank fixes its problems.

title: Cancer Risk From Cellphone Radiation Is Small, Studies Show
description: Do cellphones cause cancer?

title: Carter Page, Ex-Trump Aide Once Shunned by Right, Is Back at the Center of the Russia Case
description: For months, Carter Page, the former Trump campaign adviser who was under government surveillance as part of the Russia investigation, has been shunned by Republicans and dismissed by the White House, which portrayed his campaign stint as inconsequential.

title: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
description: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Payday Rules Relax on Trumps Watch After Lobbying by Lenders
description: WASHINGTON  In mid-April, hundreds of members of the payday lending industry will head to Florida for their annual retreat featuring golf and networking at a plush resort just outside Miami. The resort just happens to be the Trump National Doral Golf Club.

title: K. T. McFarland Withdraws Her Nomination to Be Ambassador to Singapore
description: WASHINGTON  K. T. McFarland, who was a deputy national security adviser in the Trump administration and then was picked to serve as ambassador to Singapore, withdrew her ambassadorial nomination on Friday after it had stalled in the Senate.

title: A Report of Sexual Misconduct, a $25,000 Payment and an Activists Abrupt Exit
description: As Black Lives Matter was growing into a social movement, the killing of Eric Garner by the police on Staten Island and the harsh treatment of teenage inmates at the Rikers Island jail complex pushed New York activists into a national spotlight.

title: Forced Into Action, Young Bruins Spark the Teams Rise
description: BOSTON  It is the time of the N.H.L. season when teams begin looking ahead to the playoffs. That the Boston Bruins can do so from such a high perch  they were in second place in the Eastern Conference entering Fridays games  is testimony to what they were able to accomplish when leaves still were on trees.

title: Aiming at Chinas Armpits: When Foreign Brands Misfire
description: BEIJING  Unilever brought its Rexona deodorant to China a decade ago, dreaming of a market with 2.6 billion armpits.

title: Gene Sharp, Global Guru of Nonviolent Resistance, Dies at 90
description: Gene Sharp, a preachers son whose own gospel of nonviolent struggle inspired velvet revolutions that toppled dictators on four continents, died on Jan. 28 at his home in Boston. He was 90.

title: Exxon Studies Climate Policies and Sees Little Risk to Bottom Line
description: Want the latest climate news in your inbox? You can sign up here to receive Climate Fwd:, our new email newsletter.

title: Amazon Effect, Meatball Edition
description: Amazon and Walmart are battling to dominate the grocery market, fueling a price war that could rearrange where America shops for food.

title: Trumps Vision for Vocational Education Gets a Tepid Reception
description: WASHINGTON  President Trumps calls this week for more vocational schools have received a lukewarm reception from the higher education community, including from the educators who teach in the programs he is championing.

title: Tillerson Tries to Soothe Troubled Allies in Latin America. Its Not an Easy Sell.
description: MEXICO CITY  Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson on Friday took on the daunting task of resetting relations with Latin America, a region where President Trumps anti-immigrant invective and his disdain for trade ties are rattling allies of the United States.

title: Is Dells Debt Load Pushing It Into a Deal?
description: As Dell Technologies publicly confirmed that it was exploring a number of potential transactions  ranging from an initial public offering to a combination with VMware, of which it owns 80 percent  much of the media coverage has focused on why its doing so.

title: Trumps Blood Sport Politics
description: For all those sour headlines about slumping ratings and player protests, the National Football League landed a dandy matchup for its marquee event. More than 110 million Americans will probably watch Sundays Super Bowl between the New England Patriots and Philadelphia Eagles. The contest will instantly become one of the most-watched programs in American history.

title: Confessions of an Unapologetic Patriots Fan
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  Im a fan of the New England Patriots, and in the circles that I move in  liberal, underdog-loving, far from New England  thats a bad thing to be. One hears that the teams coach, Bill Belichick, wrote Donald Trump a commendatory letter not long before the president took office. One hears that a Make America Great Again hat was seen hanging near the locker of the quarterback Tom Brady. President Trump and Robert Kraft, the team owner, were once big buddies and may well be again.

title: Washington Is Abuzz Over the Nunes Memo. His California District, Not So Much.
description: VISALIA, Calif.  As Washington was abuzz Friday over the release of a classified memo, Democrats and Republicans were up in arms over its allegations. And right in the middle was Devin Nunes, a Republican representative in California and the memos chief architect.

title: Review: An Our Town With Sex Offenders, in America Is Hard to See
description: A group of ex-cons in a therapy session introduce themselves, outlining the crimes that landed them in prison.

title: The Affordable Housing Crisis Is About to Get Worse
description: Many of the worst effects of the tax bill President Trump signed in December could take years to emerge. But the damage to the federal tax credit program that finances nearly all affordable housing built in America is already painfully evident. Unless Congress rescues this crucial program, a quarter million fewer affordable units will be built over the next 10 years, deepening an already serious crisis.

title: Dr. Arnold Gold, 92, Dies; Made Compassionate Care a Cause
description: Dr. Arnold Gold, a pediatric neurologist whose belief in the importance of an empathetic bedside manner led him and his wife to create a foundation to inspire young doctors to practice compassionate patient care, died on Jan. 23 in Manhattan. He was 92.

title: Dennis Edwards, Former Temptations Lead Singer, Dies at 74
description: Dennis Edwards, who became a lead singer of the Motown hitmakers the Temptations in 1968 as they embraced psychedelic funk and won Grammy Awards for the songs Papa Was a Rollin Stone and Cloud Nine, died on Thursday in Chicago. He was 74.

title: Kashyap Patel, Main Author of Secret Memo, Is No Stranger to Quarrels
description: WASHINGTON  Kashyap Patel is a lawyer who has sometimes run afoul of the rules.

title: Harassment Reckoning, Amazon Favors, Nafta and You: the Canada Letter
description: After Jian Ghomeshi was fired as the host of a popular C.B.C. Radio program in 2014 and then arrested on five charges related to sexual assault, the hashtag #BeenRapedNeverReported quickly appeared on Twitter.

title: How Trumps Allies Fanned an Ember of Controversy Into Flames of Outrage
description: WASHINGTON  The release of the memo mattered less than #releasethememo.

title: Inside a Culture of Abuse at U.S.A. Gymnastics
description: Gymnasts say that Larry Nassar is far from a one-man problem. Here are the stories of three coaches accused of sexually abusing young gymnasts for years.

title: Security Guard at 9/11 Memorial Charged With Trafficking Firearms
description: A security guard at the National September 11 Memorial and Museum and a Florida man face firearms trafficking charges after selling more than 25 guns  including a MAC-10 machine pistol  to an undercover officer, the authorities said on Friday.

title: Quotation of the Day: Flu Season With Many More Aches and Sniffles
description: Even in a good year, its a C-plus, B-minus match, and even the high-test stuff for old people is a joke.

title: Devin Nuness Nothingburger
description: Gertrude Stein once said of her hometown of Oakland, Calif., There is no there there. That about says it for Devin Nuness notorious memo, too.

title: Why I Am Leaving the F.B.I.
description: One of the greatest honors of my life was walking across the stage at the F.B.I. Academy and receiving my special agent badge from the director at the time, Robert Mueller. After 21 weeks of intensive training, my class swore an oath and became federal agents entrusted with the solemn duty of protecting Americans and upholding the Constitution.

title: Hue Prepared for a Holiday, Then the War Came
description: During the early days of January 1968, the 150,000 residents of Hue, like all Vietnamese, began preparations for their biggest event of the year, the three-day lunar new year festival of Tet. Markets were filled with once-a-year treats. Men decorated gardens with flowers and bonsai. Women gathered ingredients for holiday dishes and styled fresh designs for their ao dai tunic dresses. Vendors packed the streets in the hope of making extra money before the holiday arrived.

title: Review: In Draw the Circle, a Girl Becomes a Man
description: An autobiographical meditation on identity and presence, Mashuq Mushtaq Deens solo show, Draw the Circle, is the story of a suburban girl named Shireen and a Brooklyn man named Deen. They are the same person. And yet they are not.

title: Vitamin Rich
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  First of all, Im over the moon that Im going to be picking these weekends up with some regularity and spending more time with you. I know that these puzzles can be hard to crack, but we are a plucky band and we will help one another wrestle hitherto-unknown word beasts to the ground, tame them and make them do our bidding.

title: Corrections: February 3, 2018
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Jon Huntsman Sr., Billionaire Businessman and Philanthropist, Dies at 80
description: Jon Huntsman Sr., the son of a music teacher in the heart of the Idaho potato country who rose to become a billionaire industrialist and philanthropist in Utah and the father of that states governor, died on Friday at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 80.

title: Shorter Beer Runs in Minnesota, Just in Time for the Super Bowl
description: HUDSON, Wis.  As 73,000 fans make their way to U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis on Sunday to attend the Super Bowl, thousands of Minnesotans not lucky enough to have tickets will head to their local liquor store to grab some beer for the big game. Its a common enough experience for football fans across the country  but not in Minnesota.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Battle of the Sexes and Gifted
description: Emma Stone plays the star athlete to Steve Carells male chauvinist pig in Battle of the Sexes. And Chris Evans is a de-facto father in "Gifted.

title: Trump Wants to Aid Only Americas Friends. If Only It Were That Easy.
description: BRUSSELS  Distinguishing friends from enemies can be difficult. Sometimes friends disagree, and even enemies will occasionally do things for you that friends will not.

title: What We Talk About When We Talk About Pay Inequity
description: Early in her career, Jewelle Bickford, now a partner at Evercore Wealth Management, worked at a global bank in New York with a male colleague who was on his best behavior during the first half of the day, she said, but during and after lunch, his work ethic devolved. When he came back, you would walk by his office, and he would have his head down, Ms. Bickford said. And you knew he had had quite a few drinks.

title: At the Boxotel in Montreal, Life Is Lofty
description: Rooms start at about 165 Canadian dollars (about $131 at 80 cents to the U.S. dollar).

title: A New Orleans Restaurant Offers Creativity Between Bread Slices
description: Plenty of people regularly ate sandwiches as kids. But few, if any, have spun that experience into culinary gold like Mason Hereford, whose restaurant Turkey and the Wolf in New Orleans was lauded by Bon Apptit as Americas best new restaurant in 2017.

title: They Cant Wait to Vote: Energized Democrats Target Dominant G.O.P. in Statehouses
description: NEWTOWN, Pa.  For Republicans in the states, the political warning signs keep mounting: In Virginia, it was an electoral shellacking that nearly snapped their 20-year grip on the State House. In Wisconsin, it was a midwinter rout in a special election for the State Senate, fought in a conservative district.

title: How a Crowdsourced List Set Off Months of #MeToo Debate
description: On the morning of Oct. 11, a week after The New York Times exposed Harvey Weinsteins systematic harassment and assault of women in Hollywood, a 28-year-old writer, Moira Donegan, created a Google spreadsheet before heading to her job as an assistant editor at The New Republic. The purpose of the anonymous document was to name names, specifically, the names of men in the media industry described by female colleagues as sexists, sexual harassers and rapists.

title: Most Afghans Cant Read, but Their Book Trade Is Booming
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Nuts come in from Iran and fresh fruit from Pakistan, even though Afghanistan grows both in abundance. Years of bloated foreign aid budgets have produced high salaries, destroying local industries. As a result, about the only thing the country does not import is opium.

title: Jump on the Bandwagon of a Winning Super Bowl N.F.L. Team? Not These Cleveland Browns Fans
description: CLEVELAND  It all started with a woof.

title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
description: Welcome to the weekend. Super Bowl Sunday is upon us. So get those wings ordered if you need to or get thee to a grocery store to grab ingredients for your favorite nachos (I am fond of these highbrow nachos, but Ive got friends in low places, too). If football is not your thing, and even if it is, here are some articles to exercise your brain. Read on!

title: Pyeongchangs Winding Path From Obscurity to Olympics Fame
description: PYEONGCHANG, South Korea  Lee Ji-seol was in elementary school when her hometown, Pyeongchang, first applied to host the Winter Olympics. During a visit by Olympic officials, she recalled, her entire class lined up on a street to cheer and wave flags.

title: Listen to Dear Sugars: Updates From Scared to Choose Wrong and Aspiring Warrior for Love
description: Scared to Choose Wrong started second-guessing her relationship when her fianc put on some extra weight. A transgender man, who called himself Aspiring Warrior for Love, gave up on love because he felt he didnt fit the standard definition of masculinity.

title: Confirm or Deny: Tim Robbins
description: Maureen Dowd: Donald Trump reminds you of your late pal Don Rickles.

title: Hollywood Is Changing, Says Its Veteran Activist, Tim Robbins
description: So Tim Robbins and Donald Trump walk into a bar.

title: Angelina Jolies Lawyer Now Offers Quickie Divorces Online
description: Since couples now meet online, plan weddings online, cheat online and find couples therapists online, it is only logical that they should be able to divorce online.

title: This Work Helps the Living
description: Luis Lora, 49, is a master tissue technician at MTF Biologics in Edison, N.J., where he processes human tissue that can be used to treat sick or injured patients.

title: Everyday Excellence
description: As a child, I learned during our shortest month about Martin and Malcolm, Harriet and Sojourner. At home and in school they told of Benjamin Bannekers almanacs, Madam C.J. Walkers hair products and subsequent wealth, George Washington Carvers peanuts, Crispus Attuckss heroism in dying first, and even what Dr. Ben Carson did with those conjoined twins.

title: Whos Able-Bodied, Anyway?
description: The able-bodied are now everywhere among government programs for the poor, Republican officials point out. Theyre on food stamps. Theyre collecting welfare. Theyre living in subsidized housing. And their numbers have swelled on Medicaid, a program that critics say was never designed to serve them.

title: Dozens Are Killed Daily in Afghanistan. Sometimes, the Dead Turn Up Alive.
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan war takes about five dozen lives a day.

title: Secret Alliance: Israel Carries Out Airstrikes in Egypt, With Cairos O.K.
description: The jihadists in Egypts Northern Sinai had killed hundreds of soldiers and police officers, pledged allegiance to the Islamic State, briefly seized a major town and begun setting up armed checkpoints to claim territory. In late 2015, they brought down a Russian passenger jet.

title: Lasers Reveal a Maya Civilization So Dense It Blew Experts Minds
description: They were hidden there, all this time, under the cover of tree canopies in the jungles of northern Guatemala: tens of thousands of structures built by the Maya over a millennium ago.

title: This Is Why Uma Thurman Is Angry
description: Yes, Uma Thurman is mad.

title: A Peruvian Legend Goes Old School at a New Lima Taberna
description: The trick of Gastn Acurios latest restaurant, El Bodegn, is to make you believe it has always existed on this quiet corner in the Miraflores neighborhood. Mr. Acurio, Perus most famous chef, with a global empire of 50 restaurants, kept the name and much of the design of the previous restaurant in order to evoke a classic Limea taberna. The walls are covered in old portraits of famous footballers and Peruvian celebrities. Classic rock  Sting, Clapton, the Beatles  plays in the background. Mostly local workers fill the intimate space, textured with  dark wood, brick and marble tables, during a late lunch.

title: The Nunes Memo Is All Smoke, No Fire
description: The #Memo has been released. This document from House Republicans promises to detail government abuses surrounding 2016 election surveillance. But the memo is more confusing than illuminating. It doesnt so much provide evidence about abuses as make arguments that cant be evaluated based on the facts it discloses.

title: Possible Mold in the Walls and an Unresponsive Board
description: Q. I live in a co-op in Midtown West. My living room wall abuts the wall of a new building. My wall was damaged during its construction, and mold keeps growing on it. Because of a licensing agreement between my co-op board and the new development, the developers contractors have cleaned the mold and replaced the dry wall three times in two years. But, they do not share the mold test results with me, nor have they provided me with remediation paperwork; they say that verbal confirmation is enough. My co-op board and managing agent are not helping me get the paperwork either, ignoring my written requests. What can I do?

title: Our 10 Most Popular Recipes Right Now
description: From Italian potato-pasta soup with greens (above) to risotto with sausage and parsley, here are the recipes you need to cook.

title: How Tall Is Mount Everest? For Nepal, Its a Touchy Question.
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  Mount Everest is the tallest mountain in the world, but precisely how tall is it?

title: Trump Says Republican Memo Totally Vindicates Him
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump said on Saturday that a partisan memo released by House Republicans totally vindicates him in the investigation into Russian election interference, complaining that the witch hunt would go on and on even though there had been no collusion or obstruction of justice.

title: U.S. Pays Billions for Assisted Living, but What Does It Get?
description: WASHINGTON  Federal investigators say they have found huge gaps in the regulation of assisted living facilities, a shortfall that they say has potentially jeopardized the care of hundreds of thousands of people served by the booming industry.

title: Before the Games, a Competition to Chase North Koreans
description: GANGNEUNG, South Korea  A couple dozen South Korean reporters bumped and jostled one another while trying to keep up with Ryom Tae-ok and Kim Ju-sik, the Olympic figure skating pair from North Korea, as they racewalked toward the exits after a practice at the Gangneung Ice Arena on Saturday afternoon.

title: As the Super Bowl Approaches, Republicans Are Souring on the N.F.L. Again
description: How Republicans feel about the league depends on how long it has been since Trump mentioned it

title: As F.B.I. Took a Year to Pursue the Nassar Case, Dozens Say They Were Molested
description: For more than a year, an F.B.I. inquiry into allegations that Lawrence G. Nassar, a respected sports doctor, had molested three elite teenage gymnasts followed a plodding pace as it moved back and forth among agents in three cities. The accumulating information included instructional videos of the doctors unusual treatment methods, showing his ungloved hands working about the private areas of girls lying facedown on tables.

title: New Doubts in Natalie Woods Death: I Dont Think She Got in the Water by Herself
description: New witness statements have re-energized the investigation into the drowning of Natalie Wood, the child star turned Hollywood icon who disappeared off a yacht over Thanksgiving weekend in 1981.

title: When They Zig, We Zag: How The New York Times Covers the Super Bowl
description: Every January, the N.F.L. season hurtles toward its close as teams are eliminated from the playoffs one by one. Then, poof, just two remain, and suddenly the Super Bowl is upon us.

title: Unlocking Secrets of Sour Flavors With Something Found in Your Ears
description: Of the five tastes  sweet, salty, sour, bitter and umami  sour is one of the most mysterious. Bite into a piece of lemon and  bing!  your brain gets a message that something sour has arrived. But unlike sweet and bitter, for example, for which biologists have identified proteins on the tongues taste cells that detect the molecules involved, the sourness of acids like lemon juice and vinegar has remained enigmatic, with the exact details of how we pick up on it little understood. Now, however, in a paper published last month in Science, researchers report that they have found a protein in mouse taste cells that is likely a key player in the detection of sour flavors.

title: Variety: Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Its metacrostic day, when we get to put our sharp and shiny minds to solving an encoded, complex set of clues to fill out a literary passage about another encoded, complex industry (that can also be a hobby). Meta!

title: Taking a Knee and Taking Down a Monument
description: For more coverage of race, sign up here to have our Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.

title: The Memo Doesnt Vindicate Trump. Its More Proof of Obstruction.
description: For weeks, allies of President Trump ratcheted up pressure to release the memo. The impact, according to supporters, would be monumental: It would shake the F.B.I. to its core (Representative Jeff Duncan of South Carolina) or it would reveal abuses 100 times bigger than what incited the American Revolution (Sebastian Gorka, a former White House official).

title: In New Orleans, Whispers of Haiti Become a Brassy Mardi Gras Shout
description: NEW ORLEANS  Rgine Chassagne was standing barefoot in her rambling New Orleans home on a recent weekday, showing members of the Preservation Hall Jazz Band how to play the horn parts for her latest musical project.

title: Beyond the Slave Trade, the Cadaver Trade
description: The topic of slavery features prominently in each Februarys reflections on African-American history. But when it comes to this darkest time in our countrys past, experts are still discovering horrors that have not yet made their way into history books.

title: Trumps Unparalleled War on a Pillar of Society: Law Enforcement
description: WASHINGTON  In the days before the 2016 election, Donald J. Trump expressed great respect for the courage of the F.B.I. and Justice Department for reopening the investigation into Hillary Clintons private email server. Sixteen months later, he has changed his mind.

title: Nickelodeon Lines Up With the N.F.L., Confident Children Will Cheer
description: MINNEAPOLIS  As knowledge about head trauma and concussions has increased over the past decade, a growing number of parents have warned their children about the perils of football. Icons of the sport like Bo Jackson have said they would not have played had they known what we know now, while others have said they would actively discourage their children and grandchildren from playing.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 11 at Pakistani Army Base
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least 11 soldiers, including an army captain, were killed and 13 others were injured Saturday when a suicide bomber detonated his explosives at a highly guarded army base in northern Pakistan, officials said.

title: In South Africa, One Question Dominates: How Much Longer Should Zuma Stay?
description: JOHANNESBURG  It is, in South Africas political parlance, the season of the two centers of power.

title: 4,000 Opera Costumes. One Giant Fantasy Sale.
description: AMSTERDAM  The frog with the skippy ball must go.

title: Facing Death and the Dying
description: To the Editor:

title: What Its Like to Live in a Surveillance State
description: Imagine that this is your daily life: While on your way to work or on an errand, every 100 meters you pass a police blockhouse. Video cameras on street corners and lamp posts recognize your face and track your movements. At multiple checkpoints, police officers scan your ID card, your irises and the contents of your phone. At the supermarket or the bank, you are scanned again, your bags are X-rayed and an officer runs a wand over your body  at least if you are from the wrong ethnic group. Members of the main group are usually waved through.

title: Americas Last Slave Ship, and Slaverys Stain
description: The crime of importing enslaved people into the United States had been a federal offense for more than 50 years and was punishable by death when, on the eve of the Civil War, the Alabama businessman Timothy Meaher bragged that he could sail a shipful of niggers right into Mobile Bay under the officers noses.

title: The Scariest Catholic in America
description: The Rev. James Martin is a Roman Catholic rock star. His books, including one on Jesus Christ and another on the saints, have sold hundreds of thousands of copies. The director Martin Scorsese has twice hired him to consult on movies with religious themes. Television producers love him: Back when Stephen Colbert had his Comedy Central show, Father Martin popped up frequently as its official chaplain.

title: A Very Conflicted Football Fans Notes
description: When I was 5 years old, Sister Anne would tell us to keep our hands to ourselves. No hitting. No hitting! shed say to the class, over and over, every morning. Then the bell would ring and an hour later Mr. Millison would blow a whistle and instruct us to Hit him! Rip his head off! over and over, every afternoon. I was conflicted. But thats Kevin from Sister Annes class. I had to hit Kevin. This was Pee Wee football.

title: Woody Allen Meets #MeToo
description: Four years ago, when Woody Allen was given a lifetime achievement award by the Golden Globes, Dylan Farrow curled up in a ball on her bed, crying hysterically. Then she wrote an open letter for my blog (nobody else seemed to want to publish it) describing how, when she was 7 years old, Allen allegedly sexually assaulted her.

title: How Trump Can Keep His Vows on Opioids and Infrastructure
description: President Trump has correctly identified two big challenges that Americans want him to tackle this year  the opioid epidemic and the countrys dilapidated and overstretched infrastructure.

title: The Necessary Immigration Debate
description: One important task for a columnist is figuring out which ideas can be usefully argued over and which ones cant. The responses to my column last week urging Democrats to negotiate with Stephen Miller and Donald Trump on immigration, because a deal hammered out with restrictionists would have more durability and democratic legitimacy, were helpfully divided between the first category and the second.

title: Racial Hatred Cited After African Immigrants Are Shot in Italy
description: ROME  A gunman apparently targeting African immigrants from his car went on a drive-by shooting rampage in the central Italian city of Macerata on Saturday, wounding at least six people, one seriously, before he was arrested, officials said.

title: Russian Warplane Shot Down in Syria by Rebels, Defense Ministry Says
description: MOSCOW  A Russian fighter jet was shot down in a rebel-controlled area of Idlib Province in northern Syria on Saturday, Russias Defense Ministry said, adding that the pilot survived the initial attack by parachuting from the plane but was killed by members of a militia on the ground.

title: Paul Ryan Deletes Tweet Lauding a $1.50 Benefit From the New Tax Law
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker Paul D. Ryan faced a backlash on Saturday after he pointed to a secretarys $1.50 weekly increase in take-home pay as a sign of the Republican tax plans success.

title: Cracking Wise
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  For much of my life I considered the Sunday puzzle a multiday conquest, carrying the magazine around with me and dipping in and out whenever I felt inspired or got stuck on the train. The app came out and I gradually adopted its use for the rest of the week, but Sundays felt unwieldy, and I kept my paper habit. This year Ive resolved to do the streak  really do it, every day in 2018, no flaking  so Im working these on the phone from now on.

title: Why Iranian Women Are Taking Off Their Head Scarves
description: On Dec. 27, Vida Movahed stood bareheaded on a utility box on one of Tehrans busiest thoroughfares, waving her white head scarf on a stick. Within days, images of the 31-year-old, who was detained and then released a few weeks later, had become an iconic symbol.

title: Archaeologists in Egypt Discover 4,400-Year-Old Tomb
description: Archaeologists in Egypt have discovered a 4,400-year-old tomb near Cairo that contains rare wall paintings and is believed to belong to a high-ranking Egyptian priestess, government officials said on Saturday.

title: Quotation of the Day: Though Most Afghans Cant Read, Their Book Trade Is Booming
description: This is powerful anywhere, but in a place like Afghanistan, it can be a means of emotional survival.

title: Corrections: February 4, 2018
description: MAGAZINE

title: Kathleen McCann, Frank Scaturro
description: Kathleen Virginia McCann and Frank Joseph Scaturro were married Feb. 3 at St. Peter Catholic Church in Steubenville, Ohio. The Rev. Bradley Greer, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Alexandria Zak, Alexander Schosheim
description: Alexandria Silver Zak and Dr. Alexander Jordan Schosheim were married Feb. 3 by the Cantor Lori Shapiro at the Loews Hotel in Miami Beach.

title: Jill Filipovic, Ty McCormick
description: Jill Nicole Filipovic and Ty Lohrer McCormick were married Jan. 29 at the Talisman restaurant in Nairobi, Kenya. Diane Lucas, an assistant attorney general for the State of New York and a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life Minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Danielle Grunwald, Matthew Aibel
description: Danielle Alexandra Grunwald and Matthew Savage Aibel were married Feb. 3 at the Bowery Hotel in New York. Christopher Michael Quinlan, a friend of the couple who was ordained by the American Marriage Ministries for the occasion, officiated.

title: Rene Gray, Andrew Raff
description: Rene Nicole Gray and Andrew Lewis Raff were married Feb. 2 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau.Michael McSweeney, a staff member of the New York City clerks office, officiated . On Jan. 24, they had a private self-uniting ceremony, in which they exchanged rings and vows at the Tian Tan Buddha, an 87-foot-tall bronze statue on Lantau Island in Hong Kong.

title: Amanda Davis, Leonard Winters
description: Amanda Cate Davis and Leonard Michael Winters were married Feb. 3 at the Woodbury Jewish Center in Woodbury, N.Y. Rabbi Menashe East officiated.

title: Coray OHalloran, Marc Thibaut de Maisieres
description: Coray Lennane OHalloran and Marc Ernest Thibaut de Maisieres were married Jan. 31 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Angel L. Lopez, a staff member of the New York City clerks office, officiated. On Feb. 17, the Rev. Stefan Roth, a Roman Catholic priest, is to lead a religious ceremony at St. Mauritius Church in Zermatt, Switzerland, where he is the parish priest.

title: Chloe Wynne, George Reed III
description: Chloe Celine Wynne and George Briggs Reed III were married Feb. 3 at St. Thomas Church in New York. The Rev. Canon Carl F. Turner, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Whats on TV Sunday: Super Bowl, Puppy Bowl, Kitten Bowl
description: This Is Us gears up for an emotional episode after the Super Bowl, which features a halftime show from Justin Timberlake.

title: Boeings Pursuit of Beloved Brand in Brazil Hits Political Headwind
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The American aerospace giant Boeing is eagerly pursuing a partnership with the Brazilian jet maker Embraer as part of a global battle with its European rival, Airbus.

title: Fentanyl Adds Deadly Kick to Opioid Woes in Britain
description: KINGSTON UPON HULL, England  There was something different in the batches of heroin that circulated through this English port city over the summer, but most addicts had no idea what it was until their friends and fellow addicts, 16 in all, had died of overdoses.

title: The Rise of the Social Media Fembot
description: MTVs TRL recently welcomed Poppy, a rising star with hologram-perfect skin, an avant-garde Japanese schoolgirl wardrobe and a voice like Betty Boops on benzos.

title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: 3 Yale Terrace, West Orange

title: Saturday Night Live: Trump Calls In to Fox & Friends
description: Get attached to any New York institution and you will eventually see it replaced by something more contemporary, whether its the 7-Eleven that takes over the space of your favorite corner bodega or a new set of Saturday Night Live cast members who get handed the reins of its long-running parody of Fox & Friends.

title: F.B.I., Syria, Super Bowl: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here are the weeks top stories, and a look ahead.

title: Fatal Amtrak Crash in South Carolina Is New Challenge for Rail Service
description: CAYCE, S.C.  Amtrak suffered its third high-profile crash in less than seven weeks early Sunday when a passenger train traveling on the wrong track slammed into a stationary freight train in South Carolina, killing two people and intensifying worries about the safety and reliability of passenger rail service in the United States.

title: In the Super Bowl City, Building the Rings
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The sporting world will have to wait until Sunday night to find out whether the New England Patriots or the Philadelphia Eagles will win the Super Bowl. Jostens, the Minnesota company that has made rings for the winning and losing teams for decades, doesnt have that luxury.

title: Trump to Withdraw Nomination of Climate Skeptic as Top Environmental Adviser
description: Want the latest climate news in your inbox? You can sign up here to receive Climate Fwd:, our new email newsletter.

title: Why Is James Browns Estate Still Unsettled? Ask the Lawyers
description: It seems fair to say, 11 years after James Browns death, that his estate planning has failed in its major mission: to distribute his wealth efficiently.

title: Bodies of 20 Migrants Pulled From Sea Off Spanish Enclave in Africa
description: MADRID  The authorities in Spain and Morocco extended a search-and-rescue operation at sea on Sunday after recovering the bodies of at least 20 African migrants a day earlier off Melilla, a Spanish enclave in northern Africa.

title: Ex-Albany Insider Is Expected to Tell All, if He Can Be Believed
description: By the time that Todd R. Howe, the Albany insider turned government witness, begins his testimony in a major public corruption trial in Manhattan this week, his reputation will have already preceded him.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Good morning. I was talking to the international pizza consultant Anthony Falco the other day. Seriously, that is his job: international pizza consultant. He travels around the world in sweatpants and a ball cap, with some spare dishwasher shirts and sourdough starter in his bag, helps people open pizzerias, or helps them make already-open pizzerias better pizzerias. Its a cool gig.

title: Early Facebook and Google Employees Form Coalition to Fight What They Built
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A group of Silicon Valley technologists who were early employees at Facebook and Google, alarmed over the ill effects of social networks and smartphones, are banding together to challenge the companies they helped build.

title: Deadly Amtrak Crash in South Carolina
description: An Amtrak train traveling from New York to Miami hit stationary freight train early Sunday, killing at least two people and injuring at least 116 others.

title: Gowns, Wurst and Protesters: Its Ball Season in Vienna
description: VIENNA  Black tie and satin gowns. Horse-drawn carriages. Waltzes, cha-chas and tangos until the wee hours. High-society revelers scarfing down Wiener wurst with their fingers.

title: Thousands of ISIS Fighters Flee in Syria, Many to Fight Another Day
description: WASHINGTON  Thousands of Islamic State foreign fighters and family members have escaped the American-led military campaign in eastern Syria, according to new classified American and other Western military and intelligence assessments, a flow that threatens to tarnish American declarations that the militant group has been largely defeated.

title: Turkeys Worst Day Yet in Syria Offensive: At Least 7 Soldiers Killed
description: KOBANI, Syria  Turkeys military suffered its worst day yet in the two-week offensive in Afrin, Syria, when at least seven soldiers were killed and a tank was destroyed in the fighting, official Turkish news outlets reported on Sunday.

title: 100 Years On, Posters Offer Window Into Struggles of U.K. Suffragists
description: LONDON  They were wrapped in plain brown paper and addressed to the librarian at the University of Cambridge.

title: What It May Take to Strike a Segregationists Name From a Georgia Bridge: Hundreds of Girl Scouts
description: SAVANNAH, Ga.  The bridge that carries Highway 17 into Savannah is hard to miss: Its H-shaped towers are among the tallest structures for miles. But many people in the city would like never to lay eyes again on the green and white signs that say the span honors the segregationist former Gov. Eugene Talmadge.

title: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: An Oral History of Angels in America
description: When Angels in America premiered on Broadway in 1993, The New York Timess Frank Rich called it the most thrilling American play in years. Tony Kushners two-part epic about American life, set against the AIDS crisis and Ronald Reagans presidency, quickly became, by consensus, one of the 20th centurys most essential works of theater. (The play is coming back to New York, at the Neil Simon Theater, beginning previews this month and opening in March.) In 2016, Slate published an oral history of the show, in which Mr. Kushner and more than 50 others talked about the productions long and often difficult road to success. Now the authors of that history  Isaac Butler, a theater director himself, and Dan Kois, an editor and writer for Slate  have published a new book that expands on it: The World Only Spins Forward: The Ascent of Angels in America. The book covers the development and life of the play, as well as Mike Nicholss adaptation of it as a mini-series for HBO in 2003. Below, Butler and Kois talk about the influence of the political climate on their book, a film adaptation of Angels that never came to pass and more.

title: Venice Carnival Brings Out the Masks, Regattas and Revelry
description: In Venice, Italy, its that time again.

title: How the Eagles Won Their First Super Bowl Title, Drive by Drive
description: Everything had lined up for the New England Patriots to once again storm to a last-minute Super Bowl victory, but Brandon Graham, a standout defensive end for the Philadelphia Eagles, shot through the offensive line and his strip sack of Tom Brady ended the threat, handing the Eagles a shocking 41-33 upset in Super Bowl LII and the teams first championship since 1960.

title: Has Carles Puigdemont Finally Run Out of Road?
description: BRUSSELS  The police seek him in Spain. Journalists seek him in Belgium. His whereabouts usually remains a mystery, turning the exile of Carles Puigdemont, the once and would-still-be leader of Catalonia, into a real-life game of Wheres Waldo.

title: The Life and Death of Nigel, the Worlds Loneliest Seabird
description: LONDON  The story of a lonely seabird named Nigel who tried to woo a mate that had a heart of stone and died on an uninhabited island off New Zealand has captivated many on social media.

title: From San Juan to New York, He Offers Help and Hope for the Uprooted
description: Rafael Ocasio Barreto refused to leave Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria tore through his part of San Juan, Cao Martin Pea, flooding streets with dirty water, toppling power lines and destroying houses. He soldiered on for two weeks, although he was just as devastated as his community. Finally, his friends forced him  wearing just the clothes on his back  to get on a plane to the States.

title: Greeks Protest to Defend Right to the Name Macedonia
description: ATHENS  More than 100,000 people gathered in the Greek capital on Sunday to stage the biggest demonstration in decades against the inclusion of the word Macedonia in the name of a neighboring former Yugoslav republic, saying it implies a territorial claim on a northern Greek region.

title: North Koreas Would-Be Olympics: A Tale of a Cold War Boondoggle
description: SEOUL, South Korea  During the Cold War, the one-upmanship between North and South Korea was so intense that it extended to the height of the flagpoles at their border. So when the South hosted the Summer Olympics in 1988, it was no surprise that the North tried to do it one better in 1989.

title: Review: Lafayettes Double Bill of Baroque Opera and Dance Drama
description: The spirit behind Opera Lafayettes new double bill is so enterprising that you applaud the idea as much as the achievement. Both works are Baroque; both are set in a dark forest; both take their stories from the 16th-century Italian poet Torquato Tasso. Opera Lafayette, a company based in Washington, D.C., plays both pieces with period instruments. The program  half opera, half dance-drama  reached the Gerald W. Lynch Theater in Manhattan on Friday night.

title: F.B.I., Syria, Super Bowl: Your Monday Briefing
description: Heres your Morning Briefing:

title: After Years of Investigation, a Sudden Folding of the Case Against Menendez
description: Five days after the Department of Justice announced that it would retry Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, the judge in the case all but ripped out its core. Prosecutors, he said in an 53-page opinion, had failed to prove that the senator, a Democrat, had accepted hundreds of thousands of dollars in campaign contributions in exchange for lobbying on behalf of his co-defendant.

title: Winchester Claims No. 3 at Box Office Amid Super Bowl Slowdown
description: LOS ANGELES  In their Super Bowl tradition, the major Hollywood studios sat on the sidelines over the weekend. Only one new low-cost movie, the horror-themed Winchester, arrived in wide release, an effort by a small film company to counterprogram the big game by going after female ticket buyers.

title: Let Them Eat French Fries
description: In a now-deleted tweet, which has nonetheless already become notorious, Paul Ryan tried to hype the benefits of his massive corporate tax cut by celebrating the example of a worker whos getting $1.50 more per week. Thats roughly the price of a small French fries at McDonalds.

title: Labor Dept. Plan Could Let the Boss Pocket the Tip
description: The Trump administration is moving to give restaurants and other employers more control over workers tips. But critics have denounced the plan as legalizing wage theft and accuse the administration of suppressing evidence that lends credence to the charge.

title: Enablers in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: No Value in Fake Followers
description: To the Editor:

title: Does America Need a Third Party?
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertisers Eschew Politics for Humor in Super Bowl Commercials
description: Last years Super Bowl featured several ads that were political in nature. This year, companies focused more on humor and nostalgia.

title: Top North Korean Official Will Visit South Korea During Olympics
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea plans to send a high-level government delegation to South Korea to attend the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics this week, South Korean officials said on Sunday.

title: Lin Bolen, a Trailblazing TV Executive, Dies at 76
description: Lin Bolen, who as the executive in charge of NBCs daytime programming in the early 1970s was the highest-ranking woman in television, died on Jan. 18 in Santa Monica, Calif. Most online sources put her age at 76.

title: Amazon Asked for Patience. Remarkably, Wall Street Complied.
description: Allen Gillespie is one lonely stock analyst.

title: Remembering the Four Chaplains and Their Ultimate Sacrifice
description: KEARNY, N.J.  Each year on the first Sunday in February, St. Stephens Roman Catholic Church here rings with the remembrance of a selfless act of valor now 75 years old.

title: A Call to Cut Back Online Addictions. Pitted Against Just One More Click.
